“Welcome to Hogwarts,” Dumbledore said as Remus looked around the room at the students from other schools. The Triwizard Tournament was occurring this year, which explained the foreign students and the upset feeling in his gut.

The brunette looked at the table because he didn’t want to deal with this currently. He had researched the tournament when informed it would be occurring this year, and found it stupid and dangerous. Who the hell put kids into a tournament that could potentially kill them?

“Drop the gloomy expression, Lupin, there are charming girls around,” Sirius whispered as he nudged at him to make the brunette look up at him with an annoyed expression.

“Of course all you’re thinking about are the girls surrounding us,” he said before he put his attention back to the wooden table. His fingers traced over the patterns in the wood before he looked at the headmaster.

“Our sisters from Beauxbatons Academy and brothers from Drumstrang Institute have joined us this year to experience the Tri Wizard Tournament, but you must be 15 years old to enter. This tournament is not for the faint of heart and the eternal glory will be worth everything you’ve ever dreamed of,” Dumbledore explained before he showed the students the Goblet of Fire.

“We should all enter,” James said and Remus looked over at the boy across the table from him to see the black haired boy with an excited expression. Remus responded with an annoyed look at his friends and a sigh.

“I most definitely will not and neither should any of you. It’s dangerous and we could die,” Remus said and Sirius rolled his eyes at the brunette, which almost made Remus strangle him.

“Come on, so many people will be entering and we’ll most definitely not be chosen. It’ll make Lily think I’m brave. Or maybe one of those hot French girls,” James said with a wink and Remus shook his head and then looked back to Dumbledore to ignore the conversation. He was tired of hearing his friends constantly talk about the girls surrounding them at all times.

The brunette didn’t care if the chances were slim, because he wouldn’t be taking any. At 15 years old, he didn’t think he was ready to compete to the death (sure, it wasn’t to the death, but it would be his luck to die). He chuckled to himself, because for a suicidal kid; he was picky on how he wanted to die.

Once again, Sirius nudged at Remus and the brunette blinked his eyes and looked at the other. He had zoned out, something he did a lot of now.

“Peter had decided to not do it, but James and I are going to. We’re thinking of waiting until it’s the most crowded to do it or maybe just do it on Saturday,” Sirius said and Remus rolled his eyes.

“I’m glad Peter listens to me.”

“Well, you’re welcome to join us by either just coming and watching or putting your name in,” Sirius said and Remus sighed before nodding to joining. He wouldn’t be joining the competition, but just joining them as an audience member to watch them put their names into the goblet. Maybe he could talk sense into them before they decided to do so.

“I really hope neither of you get chosen,” Remus said and Sirius chuckled before the two noticed food had filled the table. Talk of the tournament had ended the moment the four started to eat, and Remus was grateful because of it.

“Listen, do you know how many Hogwarts’ students are going to enter this thing? A shit ton, so you need to realize how we’ll most likely not be chosen,” James explained once again to Remus as the four boys sat in the dormitory.

“It’s not based off chances though, it’s based off who it thinks is worthy and how far a person is will to go to win. What if it thinks you’re worthy? What if it thinks you actually want to be chosen?” Remus asked and James groaned at the questions.

“Do you really think a magical goblet will think Sirius and I are worthy enough? No offense, Sirius,” James said and the other black hair boy rolled his eyes at the comment. He wasn’t hurt by it, but it was annoying to be spoken about as if he wasn’t there.

“Say it picks one of us for some reason, what’s the harm in competing? There’s been one death in the entire span of it, so it seems pretty safe,” Sirius said and Remus gritted his teeth at the statement. Of course Sirius would try to justify it.

“Just because someone survived from jumping off a bridge doesn’t mean you should do it,” Remus said and Sirius looked at him confused.

“Someone jumped off a bridge?”

“How are you so fucking stupid sometimes?” Remus asked as he pinched the bridge of his nose and then gestured with his hands as he spoke. “It’s a figure of speech, do you know what that is?”

“Yes, I do, but I thought a task had been to jump off a bridge once,” Sirius said and Remus shut his eyes and took another deep breath in.

“I was trying to say that just because people have survived in the past doesn’t mean that everyone always will. The tasks are fucking dangerous. Do you not remember Dumbledore saying that this isn’t for the faint of heart?”

“I don’t think either of us will be chosen and there’s no harm in entering. If you could get Lily to come, then maybe she’ll think I’m super cool and date me,” James said and Remus shook his head.

“Not rewarding this stupid idea,” the brunette said and then Peter spoke up.

“How are you guys certain it won’t pick you?” Peter asked and Remus pointed at the other in agreement, the smug look on his face pissed Sirius off slightly.

“It most likely doesn’t pick the youngest contestants, because obviously we’re not the best just yet. Also neither of us want to really be in the competition, just have the attention that comes with entering,” James said as if it was clear as day.

“But what if it does pick you, James? What if Lily just thinks you’re stupid for entering and getting chosen?” Peter asked and the black haired boy rubbed his eyes before looking at him.

“If I’m a champion, then maybe some cute French girl and I can be a thing,” James said and Remus laughed at that. It wasn’t that he doubted his friend being capable of doing it, but it was the fact his friend wouldn’t let go of Lily Evans no matter what happened.

“All of this is still a bad idea according to me. I’m just worried you guys will actually get chosen, and I don’t want anything bad happening to you,” Remus said and Peter nodded in agreement.

“Don’t worry, Moony. I promise neither of us will be chosen. Let’s just go to sleep now, okay?” Sirius asked because he was tired of the arguing. It hurt his head and made him upset and uncertain on whether or not he should do it.

“Whatever,” Remus huffed as he got up to go to bathroom to brush his teeth. James stared at the door and then looked over at Sirius.

“Why is he acting like this?”

“Maybe because he’s worried about you two,” Peter suggested and the glare from James made the mousy boy stop talking.

“Can we just stop talking about it now? Obviously it’s going to be half the group against the other half in this situation,” Sirius said and James sighed. It was obvious he wanted all of them to enter, but there was no amount of convincing that would make Remus or Peter join in on their plan.

When Remus returned to the room, he looked over at Sirius with a look the long haired boy couldn’t read. The brunette got in bed, pulled the curtains to cover him completely, which wasn’t out of the ordinary, but he never said goodnight to any of them.

Remus was upset and Sirius knew it was mainly with him for agreeing to James’s plan. The problem was that even if Sirius didn’t want to enter his name, he couldn’t back out. He didn’t want James to feel alone or see him as scared, but he didn’t want to say that aloud; especially to Remus.

“Are you sure about this?” Remus asked and Sirius chuckled at the brunette. Of course he’d ask the question as they were walking to the Great Hall in order to enter.

“We’re sure, just stop asking that,” James responded and Remus sighed as the three continued to walk.

Sirius wasn’t sure if he wanted to do this, but he didn’t want James to do it alone. The thought of entering wasn’t terrifying, but the thought of becoming a champion sure was. He shook his head and tried to get to get the thoughts Remus had put in there out.

“I really don’t think this is a good idea,” Remus stated once they entered the room and Sirius laughed at that. He wanted to agree with the brunette, but he knew he couldn’t and wouldn’t.

“You never think I have good ideas,” James responded as he walked up to the cup and Remus watched as he put his name in.

“Well, quite frankly, you never do have any good ideas. Typically they’re not great, but this one is actually fairly bad,” the brunette boy told his black haired friend only to get a snort in return. “Sirius, it’s not too late to not do this.”

“Honestly, it kind of is and maybe this will help me get laid,” Sirius said before throwing his name in the fire and multiple of the foreign girls were watching him from afar. He knew they hadn’t heard what he had said because their expression didn’t hold a disgusted look.

Remus had clenched fists by his side and growled slightly at the boy. The way he acted made Sirius and James take a step back from the temperamental boy.

“You’re telling me that you’ll risk your life to get fucking laid? Your logic of how too many people entering and it won’t pick you shows how big of dumbasses you two are!” Remus yelled and Sirius tried to contain a cool demeanor instead of a frightened one.

“Maybe you need to get laid, Remy,” he said and Remus shoved at the taller boy for using the nickname he hated. Sirius didn’t know why he had used the name, especially in a time like this, but he was shoved because of it.

James quickly stepped in between the two to try to prevent a fight from breaking out. He knew Sirius wouldn’t fight back when the other was like this, but James decided to take precautions.

“Hey, Remus, let’s calm down,” James said as he slowly edged his way up to the brunette. Remus may have been two inches shorter, but in this moment it seemed like he towered over James.

He shoved James away from him, into the floor, and strutted out of the Great Hall, anger seethed from him and everyone could tell. Sirius quickly helped up the other black haired boy and sighed in the direction of where Remus had left.

“It’s near full moon,” Sirius defended and James scoffed at the comment, but Sirius knew the other knew the reason was a valid one. Remus couldn’t help how his moods and anger fluctuated, but Sirius knew this wasn’t actually just a result from the brunette being a werewolf.

“Do you think he’s actually mad at us? Like to the point where he may not talk to us,” James asked and Sirius didn’t know the answer and didn’t want to think about that. He didn’t want to think about Remus shutting them out like he had done second year after he confessed he was a werewolf.

“Let’s hope not, because we’re screwed without his brain. Sure, it was uncalled for, but we typically don’t have great ideas,” Sirius admitted and James nodded in agreement.

The two walked out of the Great Hall and saw Peter fidgeting as he walked towards them. He appeared to be fidgeting more than normal, which worried Sirius slightly.

“Hey, Peter, what’s wrong?” James asked and the nervous boy let out a deep breath.

“Remus told me to tell you two that he won’t be talking to either of you for a couple days or until he cools off. He also said don’t talk to him or he’ll hex you,” Peter said slightly rushed and the two black haired boys stared at him in disbelief.

“Just because we put our names in the goblet?” Sirius asked and Peter shook his head. Of course there would be more so Remus could feel justified in his actions.

“He thinks you two don’t care about him or his opinion,” Peter said and James scoffed at the statement only to realize the brunette was being honest.

“Are you bloody kidding me? We do one thing and he acts like a child!” James yelled and Sirius just remained quiet. Usually he’d be the one yelling, but he understood why Remus felt that way. The werewolf boy had asked them to not do it repeatedly, but they ignored him and kept telling him how it would be okay.

“We didn’t listen to him about something that could put us in harm’s way, which scares him,” Sirius said and James stopped yelling once the other spoke. “He’s scared we’ll be picked and then die.”

“The chances of that are slim though, doesn’t he realize that? I thought this out, but he doesn’t care about that,” James complained and Sirius sighed in response. He was upset along with James, but he also had listened to everything Remus had said.

Neither of them spoke to the brunette boy. James didn’t speak to him because he was angry at him as well, but Sirius didn’t speak to him because he wasn’t in the mood to get hexed.

At first, Sirius and James didn’t think Remus would actually shut them out, but when he didn’t come to support them during their Qudditch practices, sat away from them at meals, and ignored the assigned seating so he wasn’t near them; the duo started to worry.

They had known he was upset, but didn’t realize it was this to extent. Nearly a week had gone by when Sirius decided he’d just talk to the brunette. It didn’t matter to him if he got hexed as long as he got to speak to his best friend.

“Remus, we need to talk,” Sirius said as he sat across the table from the other in the common room. The scarred boy looked up from his homework and rolled his eyes.

“No,” he said before he looked back down at his homework and ignored the black haired boy seated across from him.

“Why are you so pissed? We put our names in there, so what? It never meant we don’t care about you or anything you say,” Sirius said and Remus looked up at him his an annoyed expression. The black haired boy worried it would turn into an aggressive one soon, but he tried to remain calm.

“I’m sorry I don’t want my friends to die, my fucking bad,” Remus snapped before he slammed his book shut and looked at the other with an enraged look. “You get pissed at me constantly because I do something you don’t like, but the moment I get pissed; I’m being unreasonable!”

“Mate, it’s just that we never fucking acted or said we didn’t care about you. We invited you to come with us and you did. We invited you to join us in putting your name in and you didn’t. We didn’t pressure you into anything, but we wanted to do it,” Sirius said and he tried to remain calm for his own sake. If he blew up, then Remus would blow up ten times worse.

Remus looked at him with an expressionless face and it terrified the other boy, but Sirius didn’t let his fear show. The scarred face brunette sighed and licked his lips as he thought, something he did quite regularly.

“I’m just scared,” Remus whispered and Sirius nodded, because he was slightly scared too. He couldn’t admit it aloud, but maybe in this moment the other would understand how scared he was too.

“I promise it’s going to be okay, neither James nor I are going to be picked. Just have some faith,” Sirius said and the other gave him a soft smile, one that wasn’t noticeable unless you knew him.

“Okay, I’m sorry for being a prick,” Remus muttered and Sirius smiled at him before he got up and threw an arm around the other.

“Good, now let’s go tell James the good news.”

“See that girl over there?” Sirius asked and Remus looked up from his book to see one of the French girls staring at him only to look away quickly.

“Yeah, what about her?” Remus asked unamused and Sirius gave him an annoyed look.

“She’s been checking you out all this time, but all you ever do is check out books,” Sirius said and James laughed at the joke his friend had made.

It was only the three boys since Peter was in detention for cheating on a test. McGonagall was being rough this year and the other boy had been stupid to think he could’ve gotten away with it.

“I’d rather learn about the world than learn about some girl I’ll never see again after this year,” the brunette said before he turned his attention back down to his book.

“It’s called a one night stand, Moony,” James said and Remus looked over at him, through Sirius.

“I taught you what that word was, along with the majority of your vocabulary, so shut the hell up,” he snapped and over the last couple weeks the brunette had only grown grumpier and more aggressive. No one knew why because he was still fairly closed off from his friends since the last fight had happened.

“She’s staring again,” Sirius commented, not paying attention to his friends squabbling. The other two were always bickering, so Sirius never paid attention to it unless there was actual yelling involved.

The girl caught the stare of Sirius and he could tell she felt embarrassed by being caught, but still turned her attention back over to the brunette next to him. Although Sirius wasn’t listening, he could tell the brunette was still arguing with James and it gave him time to observe the other.

It wasn’t that Sirius thought Remus was unattractive by any means, but it was weird for foreign girls to find the scarred face attractive when a lot of people at Hogwarts didn’t. Maybe the scars made him attractive? Or maybe the freckles that were located upon his cheeks and nose were what drew others in?

“What the hell are you looking at?” Remus asked with a hit of the black haired boy’s shoulder and Sirius blinked his eyes a couple time before he shrugged. Had he really been staring at Remus so intensely he got lost in his own thoughts?

“I was just thinking, guess I looked over at you at the wrong time,” Sirius lied because he wasn’t going to admit how he had been analyzing the freckles scattered across the other’s face.

“Whatever, just don’t do it again? It was weird,” Remus said before he opened his book and started to read once more. Sirius looked over to see James no longer next to him but across the room next to Lily Evans.

James had a way of looking at Lily, almost as if he wanted to know every detail about her appearance. Sirius watched as the smile on James face diminished when he was most likely rejected once more and then the smile reappeared when he probably said how he’d never give up.

“Do you think he’s serious when he says he’ll never give up?” Remus asked and Sirius snorted.

“Obviously I’m Sirius, he’s James. To think you call us your best friend,” Sirius joked for a second and then noticed the annoyed expression of Remus’s face. “I think he’s never going to give up, because it’s a promise when he says it.”

Remus fell silent once more and Sirius watched James walk over to the two. He had a smile on his face, something he told Sirius was how he’d never cry or frown in public after being rejected. He didn’t want to seem weak for his feelings and Sirius understood that, but he wondered if it was because they both came from pureblood houses.

“We should get going, see if Pete is done with detention yet,” James said and the other two followed his lead, only to end up in an empty boys’ bathroom. “Why doesn’t she want me?”

“Mate, I think it’s more of a she doesn’t want anyone kind of thing,” Remus said, trying to provide comfort while Sirius slung an arm around his best friend’s shoulders.

“Jamie, she’ll realize soon enough, just give her time. You’re a catch,” Sirius said before messing up his already messy hair to get a huff out of the other.

“How many times do I have to tell you to not call me Jamie?”

“When you’re being girly, sometimes we have to.”

Weeks had passed and it was finally the night of announcement of the champions. All day Remus had been worried about who would be the champions, but Sirius continued to tell him it would be okay. James repeated his theory of how they wouldn’t be chosen, but his words still didn’t soothe the worried brunette.

Peter kept trying to back Sirius and James up, but he was shut down with the bitterness known as Remus Lupin. It was obvious that until the champions were announced, he wouldn’t be calm or collected about it.

The brunette fidgeted at the Gryffindor table; his legs bounced up and down and his hands strummed along the table. His fingers made an annoying drumming sound and Sirius placed his hand over the other to stop the noise. The touch made the other jump and Sirius chuckled at Remus’s nerves.

“I–I know, but I have the right to be scared, okay? I have the right to worry my friends would be chosen and fucking die?” Remus whispered over at him, worried others would hear them fight.

It didn’t matter whether or not James was alone because it wasn’t in seriousness for the other. “You know he’s mad because he feels like he didn’t try hard enough to prevent it. He’s punishing himself,” Lily said in a soft voice and James stood up and looked at her with angry eyes.

“I’m just going to go to the dorm,” Sirius said as he took a couple steps away from the two boys and was suddenly bombarded with attention of those around him.

“Sirius, it’s so amazing how you became a champion!” Emily, a sixth year, exclaimed as she threw an arm around his shoulders. He didn’t move to wrap his arm around her and it caused her to huff. “Come on, you’re a man now, at least act the part.”

When she pulled his hand up to the small of her back, he jumped away from her. Remus had shut down when he needed him most and he really didn’t want to deal with some sixth year girl trying to get with him.

James reasoning really was stupid if you thought about it, but he used it as an excuse to cover the real reason he entered. It was just he hadn’t realized he had a real reason, but Remus had realized before the other did. Maybe he’d blame his parents for the reason he entered and it would’ve been easy if Remus hadn’t of entered the room.

“You never thought you’d make it in, so it’s not greedy,” James tried to soothe him and Sirius looked over at him before he laughed slightly.

“I wanted to make it in. I wanted to have a reason show my parents I can do something they can be proud of. I thought he’d understand that,” Sirius said before he placed his face in his hands. He didn’t want to cry and he’d try his hardest not to.

A cursed love (P1)

Remus Lupin stared at the papers on his desk while at work.

He truly didn’t know what to do. The only curse breaker he knew of was Bill Weasley, who was in Egypt. Remus knew he could just apparate but he didn’t know where Bill was specifically, so couldn’t even send him an owl. Bill would be back in a few weeks, so Remus could talk to him then.

It wasn’t like Remus could go to anyone he didn’t know closely about his problem. What with the Potter family and those around them, including himself and Sirius, being celebrities. The scandal mongers, like that damn Skeeter woman, would have a field day with their issue. No. Remus couldn’t do that to him or Sirius.

A tap on his shoulder snapped Remus out of his thoughts.

“Hey,” Tonks greeted him, sitting down next to him.

“Tonks. Hello,” Remus replied.

“How are you-” Tonks looked around. She checked no one was around before continuing “- holding up? You doing okay?”

“Yeah, I’ll be alright,” Remus reassured her.

“I saw the case files. It wouldn’t take a genius to figure it out. He hasn’t… hurt you, has he?” Tonks enquired.

“No!” Remus said quickly.

“Oh Merlin, you had your… change last week too! How was that?” Tonks asked.

“I was on my own,” Remus admitted, looking down as he spoke.

Tonks’ hair flickered a red before returning to its usual purple. “You what?!”

“Noise level Tonks!” Remus reminded her, glancing around.

“Right, sorry, but really?! You were on your own?!” Tonks'eyes were wide with horror. They went wider when Remus nodded. “Oh Remus…”

“It’s not his fault,” Remus said quickly.

“I know, but why couldn’t he fight it?! Sirius is so strong-” Tonks began.

“He’s trying. He makes me things, when I’m not home. It always comes with a mess though.” Remus felt the need to defend Sirius.

Tonks nodded, and glanced at her watch. “I have to go. Be safe, Remus.”

“I will. Give Teddy my love,” Remus replied.

They hugged goodbye and Tonks dashed away.

When Remus got home, there was tea on the table.

“Thank you. I love you!” He called out. That was all he could do, remind Sirius, who he knew would be in agony over his treatment of Remus, that he loved him and that he wouldn’t ever blame him.

“Shut up!” Sirius yelled. That was another common occurrence, that the curse would make Sirius say awful things.

A week passed with Sirius becoming more aggressive by the day. He would yell, hit the wall, slam the door. At night, he would push Remus away, and Remus would often end up on the edge of the bed with no blanket.

“I forgive you. I love you. I miss you,” became the words that Remus would utter, over and over again.

Until mid way through the week, just over a week after Remus knew of the curse.

Remus guessed that Sirius had had a long day, making him too tired to fight the curse.

Sirius stormed through the door, slamming it on his way through.

“Sirius?” Remus called out.

Sirius stormed into the room.

“I’m tired, make me something to eat, you lump!” Sirius demanded. This was another new thing, that Sirius would order Remus about.

“I’m hungry too. How does an early dinner sound?” Remus replied. He would often be civil, just to pretend everything was alright.

“I don’t care! Make me something to eat!” Sirius yelled, slamming his hand down on the table next to Remus.

Remus went into the kitchen.

He reflected on the past week. A week where their house radiated hatred and loneliness. Two weeks without loving touches and Sirius’s gentle kisses. Two weeks without jokes or laughing at some silly thing.

Remus didn’t even realise he was crying until he heard Sirius storm in.

“What’s taking so long?” Sirius demanded.

Remus looked up, but only just.

“Don’t just stand there sniveling! I asked you to do something!” Sirius yelled. At this, Remus’s lips twitched up a bit, recalling what they would call Severus in their youth.

“What’s so funny?” Sirius demanded.

“Just memories, my love, just memories,” Remus replied.

“I’ll show you memories!” Sirius picked up a plate and stormed over.

Remus put his hands over his head, waiting for the impact.

“NO!” Sirius shouted suddenly. “NO I WON’T LET YOU HURT HIM!” Sirius put the plate down and stumbled to the other side of the kitchen, hands over his face, his back to Remus.

“Sirius?” Remus said gently.

“I’m sorry Moony, I’m so so sorry!” Sirius sobbed.

“Padfoot, my love, my stars, you know I don’t blame you,” Remus told him gently. Remus moved to get closer, to comfort his boyfriend.

“Don’t,” Sirius said quickly. “I don’t want to hurt you. Please don’t come closer. If you come closer it makes it harder to fight it.”

“Ok. I won’t come closer,” Remus assured him.

“You should leave, Moony. Get away from here, get away from me,” Sirius insisted.

“I won’t leave you Sirius,” Remus said firmly.

“It’s not like I want this Remus! Merlin, I just want to hold you. I swear, when this is broken, I’m going to make it up to you. We can take the week, at least, off of work the both of us, and just hold each other. I’ll wait on you, hand and foot. I’ll make it right, you’ll see,” Sirius rambled, his body heaving where he stood.

“I know. You don’t have to wait on me, but the holding each other sounds great,” Remus replied, a smile in his voice.

“I love you, Remus Lupin,” Sirius said hoarsely, the effort now taking a toll on his voice.

“I love you too, so much, Sirius Black,” Remus reassured him gently.

“Sorry for all the mess, with the food and the tea,” Sirius apologised.

“It’s fine. I appreciate it. Thank you for making it.” Remus watched Sirius’s breath become more laboured.

“I can’t fight it much longer,” Sirius admitted.

“That’s alright,” Remus assured him.

“I’m sorry.” There was a plea in Sirius’s voice, one Remus recognised as Sirius’s fear of hurting someone he loved.

“It’s alright.” Before Sirius could register what was happening, Remus moved quickly towards him, and pulled Sirius into his arms. He felt Sirius’s arms around him for a second, before he was shoved away, into the cupboard, and all went black.

When Remus awoke, he was curled up in their bed, with a healing potion and chocolate next to him.

When Remus walked out into their lounge, he saw Sirius watching some muggle tv show.

“I love you. I forgive you,” Remus declared.

In his mind, Sirius Black sobbed.

His father is English, and his mother is Persian. 

Salazar hates the Latin spells, thinks they sound ugly, while his mother’s Farsi always sounds like a song. But he’s English, and good English wizards use Latin. 

Sometimes he wants to be loud, wants to wear bright robes and speak in a language no one else uses. But he doesn’t. His ambition has always mattered more to him than his pride. Pride is for fools. 

Then he meets Godric, before either of them are anything, when Godric is still a young warrior with a wide grin, and Salazar is a travelling scholar, and he can’t help but be captivated. 

Before Godric, he hadn’t known that pride could be a virtue.

Harry Potter 20 Years Later

Are you serious right now Harry Potter turns 20

That’s a big feat for this saga that literally makes it a classic that is insane

I can’t believe that it had been that long ago

Well in the spirit of it being 20 I have a question for you…Who was your favorite Harry Potter character of the books.

Mine was snape he was quite misunderstood but he was also blunt.

There was Fred and George they had sass, which I can completely relate to people don’t know if they should laugh or at I said or not.

Then there is Author Weasley I think that is mostly becuse of the actor not the character.

It is amazing that Harry Potter came into our lives 20 years ago

It was 21 years ago that I graduated high school

Wow I feel old

And if anybody wanted to know what House I belonged to that would be Hufflepuff the Sorting hat told me so.
